Expectation1: Assemble and construct wooden frameworks, furniture, or cabinetry
Situation1: The carpenter is building custom cabinetry and needs to collaborate with other construction professionals to complete the project on time
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story:
I spent the morning sanding down the last of the custom cabinet doors, sweat beading on my brow as the foreman reminded me, again, that the client expected everything finished by Monday. The electrician was late, the plumber was grumbling, and I was the one caught in the middle, trying to keep the project on track. My mind buzzed with measurements and deadlines as I finally left the site, desperate for a break. 

On my walk through the park, I unwrapped a sandwich, barely tasting it. My hands, rough from work, clutched the wrapper as I passed a sign: “No Littering. Keep Our Park Clean.” The trash bin was a few steps away, but my phone buzzed—another message from the site, another problem. I hesitated, wrapper in hand, torn between tossing it carelessly to rush back to work or taking the extra moment to do what I knew was right as a citizen. The pressure to return and keep the cabinetry on schedule pressed against my sense of responsibility to my community. My heart pounded as I stood there, caught between the demands of my craft and my duty to the city I called home.
